Hypenotic The Jekyll Butler

It’s Lonely in a Self-Serve World

16 Nov 2011

I love grocery shopping, but I absolutely detest doing my own self-serve check out. It’s not (just) that I’m lazy, it’s that it feels like such an empty experience. I’ve never quite understood why.

Today on my way to get groceries at Fiesta Farms (our client) the sadness I feel when bagging my own started to make sense. CBC’s Q featured New York Times columnist Craig Lambert who was talking about his article Our Unpaid Extra Shadow Work.  In it Lambert talked about all of the unpaid jobs we now do that someone else did ten years ago.

Consider how self-serve gas stations, airports and grocery stores have off-loaded  tasks onto the consumer. Lambert focuses on fatigue as a consequence of all of the many extra tasks we now have to perform. But I think there’s something much bigger at stake.

Sure, I’m frustrated by the lack of service people I encounter when I’m in a store and need to ask a question. No one works in these stores anymore. They’re just there to take your money.

So why do I care? Am I looking to be pampered? Am I just spoiled?

The answer to this question was clear to me as I chatted with Sara, Lucy and Vito at the Fiesta Farms checkout counter. We were talking about Fiesta’s involvement in Movember and which male employees were and were not participating.

Fiesta Farm’s Vito (who will help you get your bags to your car)

The banter may seem insignificant, but the human engagement and a sense of community I felt is not. In fact, it’s core to the experience of shopping at Fiesta.  As Lambert states:

Doing things for one another is, in fact, an essential characteristic of a human community. Various mundane jobs were once spread around among us, and performing such small services for one another was even an aspect of civility.

Without the chit-chat and human engagement life is quite lonely. What used to be social tasks are now performed with nothing but the voices in your head to keep you engaged. We’re living a more and more isolated existence. Of course it’s ironic given the proliferation of social media like Facebook and Twitter, but in self-serve moments it’s palpable. <!--more-->

When we were doing our background research on Fiesta Farms we did a review of the kinds of blog posts people wrote about the store. One, by Krista Scott Dixon stood out. In her post she refers to small town grocery stores as “community hubs” and  says “fifteen years later, I am immersed in that world again, every time I step into Fiesta Farms. ”

Fiesta has established a competitive advantage by *not *being self-serve (what Lambert calls a synonym for “no service.”) Other indie shops like my local hardware store make a point of circling the aisles asking “can I help you with something?”  I find that tremendously valuable. So valuable that I’m willing to pay for it. And I bet I’m not alone.

But does service have to be relegated to high-end shops like Holt Renfrew where you’ll be bombarded by salespeople falling over themselves to serve you? Or is there a market for run of the mill experiences that refuse to cave into the cost-cutting self-serve trend.

Are you willing to pay for service, or are you just fine going about your own business? Do you notice the sense of isolation that comes with a self-serve world or am I just high maintenance?
